definition:
A [*finite game*]{} is a game in which each instance of the game is
designed to reach a conclusion, either as a natural consequence of
normal play, or due to the rules of the game.

For example, a game of Reversi is over when all the squares of the board
have been filled up, if not sooner. Most chess games end with one side
trapping the opponent’s king. Theoretically, certain scenarios could go
on indefinitely if both sides lack the resources to trap the opponent’s
king; for example, if White has only a king and a knight, and Black has
only the king left, Black could theoretically evade indefinitely if it
weren’t for the stalemate rule.
